#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Avoid Hazardous Cookware
#Text=The cookware you use to prepare your food may be just as important as the ingredients in your food .
#Text=Hazardous cookware can leech dangerous toxins into your food and cause health problems .
#Text=However , there are many safe alternatives to cook with .
#Text=To avoid dangerous cookware , stay away from non-stick , aluminum , copper , and BPA plastic .
#Text=Instead , choose stainless steel , cast iron , ceramic , or glass .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Eliminating Dangerous Cookware
#Text=Avoid non-stick cookware .
#Text=Non-stick cookware may be convenient , but it can be very dangerous .
#Text=Non-stick cookware may release toxic fumes if it is overheated .
#Text=These fumes can be dangerous if you inhale them .
#Text=Stay away from Teflon pans .
#Text=If you overheat Teflon pans , you may develop flu-like symptoms .
#Text=The fumes from non-stick pans may also kill pet birds .
#Text=Beware of aluminum .
#Text=Aluminum cookware may not be as safe as you ’d think .
#Text=Long-term usage of and exposure to aluminum can cause health problems .
#Text=Using aluminum cookware often can introduce more aluminum into your body than is safe .
#Text=Aluminum may damage the brain and block toxins from leaving the body .
#Text=Reconsider copper .
#Text=Copper cookware is appealing to the eye , but it may be dangerous when placed in cookware .
#Text=Copper and nickel are heavy metals that are toxic .
#Text=They are both used in the shiny finish of copper cookware .
#Text=Cooking often with this cookware may introduce these heavy metals into your food and body .
#Text=A build up of these metals in your body may negatively affect your brain and cause chronic illnesses .
#Text=If you want to use copper cookware , look for items where copper is only used on the outside .
#Text=Sometimes , copper is placed between two layers of other metals , such as stainless steel , which is safe .
#Text=Never buy cookware that has copper on the inside lining .
#Text=Throw away cookware that is damaged .
#Text=Safe cookware can become dangerous if it is damaged .
#Text=If you have non-stick cookware and the coating is coming off , throw it away .
#Text=This can be very dangerous and release toxins into your food .
#Text=If you use ceramic cookware that is cracked or chipped , get rid of it .
#Text=If the glaze contains lead , being chipped or cracked increases the risk of lead seeping into your food .
#Text=Avoid plastic cutting boards .
#Text=Plastic cutting boards can be a health hazard .
#Text=When the knife cuts into food , it leave cuts and grooves in the plastic .
#Text=These open spaces can house bacteria like E. coli and salmonella .
#Text=Choose wood or bamboo cutting boards instead .
#Text=Bacteria does n’t stick to it as much .
#Text=Look for dangers with glazed cookware .
#Text=Many glazes contain lead , and sometimes you ca n't be certain whether the cookware is lead-free or not .
#Text=If you find ceramic cookware that is lead-free , go with that .
#Text=For others , you may need to inspect it a bit more closely before using it .
#Text=Some may say on the bottom it is for decoration only and not for food .
#Text=Many glazed terracotta dishes , especially from Latin American countries , may contain lead .
#Text=Use these only for decoration ; do not eat from them .
#Text=Overly decorated tableware , especially from Asia , can pose a risk .
#Text=If there are brightly colored decorations anywhere that will touch food , use caution .
#Text=Homemade ceramics , even in the United States , may contain a lead glaze .
#Text=Talk to the person before using it with food .
#Text=Antique ceramic tableware poses a threat because it may be from before lead was outlawed .
#Text=Decorations on top of the glaze may cause a deterioration of the glaze , exposing dangerous metals such as lead .
#Text=Find the country of origin for your cookware .
#Text=Not all countries have the same laws for cookware safety .
#Text=Double check the country of origin when choosing cookware .
#Text=This may influence the types of materials used in the production .
#Text=For example , ceramic cookware made in other countries , such as Latin American or Asian countries , may contain lead and be unfit for food use .
#Text=Choosing Safe Cookware
#Text=Choose cast iron cookware .
#Text=Cast iron is a great , safe material for pots and pans .
#Text=Cast iron is also a relatively non-stick surface .
#Text=You can heat cast iron to any temperature without any dangerous fumes .
#Text=You can also place cast iron pots and pans in the oven .
#Text=You can also try enamel coated cast iron .
#Text=Try stainless steel .
#Text=Stainless steel pots and pans are safe options .
#Text=They do not release anything hazardous into your food or the air when cooking .
#Text=You can also use any cooking utensil on them without harming them .
#Text=They also contain no carcinogens .
#Text=These pans are not non-stick , so you have to add butter or oil to help keep things from sticking .
#Text=Make sure to check your stainless steel pots and pans , especially if you are buying cheaper ones .
#Text=Cheap stainless steel cookware may contain nickel and chromium , harmful metals that can seep into food .
#Text=Cook with glass .
#Text=Glass is a safe material for cookware .
#Text=Glass does n’t release anything toxic when heated and wo n’t contaminate your food .
#Text=It also does n’t hold flavors or odors in the material .
#Text=Make sure to use caution when baking with glass .
#Text=It will break if dropped .
#Text=Food will stick to glass if you do not add something to help it keep from sticking .
#Text=Try stoneware .
#Text=Stoneware is safe and nontoxic .
#Text=After a few uses , it will become non-stick .
#Text=You do n’t have to wash stoneware with soap .
#Text=You can scrape , wipe , or rinse it instead .
#Text=Stoneware also will not absorb flavors or odors .
#Text=Stoneware can crack or break if dropped .
#Text=Stoneware is more expensive than other types of cookware .
#Text=Go for ceramic .
#Text=Cookware that is made with 100 % ceramic is extremely safe .
#Text=It does n’t react when heated and is n’t toxic .
#Text=The surface of ceramic cookware will not corrode .
#Text=You can use any utensil on ceramic and put it in the dishwasher .
#Text=Ceramic cookware is expensive .
#Text=Make sure you are not purchasing cookware that has a ceramic glaze that contains lead .
#Text=This generally occurs with pieces made outside of the United States .
#Text=Research the brand and pieces to make sure it is lead-free .
#Text=Choose BPA-free plastic .
#Text=Heating food in plastic containers containing chemicals can be dangerous .
#Text=BPA can cause cancer and negatively affect the brain and heart .
#Text=Throw out any plastic that is not BPA and only buy
#Text=BPA-free containers .
#Text=If you are concerned about using plastic , consider using glass containers instead .
